messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 47 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Sample complexity of hidden subgroup problem

Paper Abstract: Abstract The hidden subgroup problem (ğ–§ğ–²ğ–¯ğ–§ğ–²ğ–¯\mathsf{HSP}) has been attracting much attention in quantum computing, since several well-known quantum algorithms including Shor algorithm can be described in a uniform framework as quantum methods to address different instances of it. One of the central issues about ğ–§ğ–²ğ–¯ğ–§ğ–²ğ–¯\mathsf{HSP} is to characterize its quantum/classical complexity. For example, from the viewpoint of learning theory, sample complexity is a crucial concept. However, while the quantum sample complexity of the problem has been studied, a full characterization of the classical sample complexity of ğ–§ğ–²ğ–¯ğ–§ğ–²ğ–¯\mathsf{HSP} seems to be absent, which will thus be the topic in this paper. ğ–§ğ–²ğ–¯ğ–§ğ–²ğ–¯\mathsf{HSP} over a finite group is defined as follows: For a finite group GğºG and a finite set Vğ‘‰V, given a function f:Gâ†’V:ğ‘“â†’ğºğ‘‰f:G\to V and the promise that for any x,yâˆˆG,fâ€‹(x)=fâ€‹(xâ€‹y)formulae-sequenceğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğºğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ‘¦x,y\in G,f(x)=f(xy) iff yâˆˆHğ‘¦ğ»y\in H for a subgroup Hâˆˆâ„‹ğ»â„‹H\in\mathcal{H}, where â„‹â„‹\mathcal{H} is a set of candidate subgroups of GğºG, the goal is to identify Hğ»H. Our contributions are as follows: i) For ğ–§ğ–²ğ–¯ğ–§ğ–²ğ–¯\mathsf{HSP}, we show that the number of uniform examples necessary to learn the hidden subgroup with bounded error is at least Î©â€‹(maxâ¡{minHâˆˆâ„‹â¡logâ¡|â„‹|logâ¡|G||H|,minHâˆˆâ„‹â¡|G||H|â€‹logâ¡|â„‹|logâ¡|G||H|})Î©subscriptğ»â„‹â„‹ğºğ»subscriptğ»â„‹ğºğ»â„‹ğºğ»\Omega\left(\max\left\{\min\limits_{H\in\mathcal{H}}\frac{\log|\mathcal{H}|}{\log\frac{|G|}{|H|}},\min\limits_{H\in\mathcal{H}}\sqrt{\frac{|G|}{|H|}\frac{\log|\mathcal{H}|}{\log\frac{|G|}{|H|}}}\right\}\right), and on the other hand, Oâ€‹(maxHâˆˆâ„‹â¡{sâ€‹râ€‹(â„‹),|G||H|â€‹sâ€‹râ€‹(â„‹)})ğ‘‚subscriptğ»â„‹ğ‘ ğ‘Ÿâ„‹ğºğ»ğ‘ ğ‘Ÿâ„‹O\left(\max\limits_{H\in\mathcal{H}}\left\{sr(\mathcal{H}),\sqrt{\frac{|G|}{|H|}sr(\mathcal{H})}\right\}\right) uniform examples are sufficient, where sâ€‹râ€‹(â„‹)=maxHâˆˆâ„‹â¡ğ—‹â€‹(H)ğ‘ ğ‘Ÿâ„‹subscriptğ»â„‹ğ—‹ğ»sr(\mathcal{H})=\max\limits_{H\in\mathcal{H}}\mathsf{r}(H) and ğ—‹â€‹(H)ğ—‹ğ»\mathsf{r}(H) is the rank of Hğ»H. ii) By concretizing the parameters of ğ–§ğ–²ğ–¯ğ–§ğ–²ğ–¯\mathsf{HSP}, we consider a class of restricted Abelian hidden subgroup problem (ğ—‹ğ– ğ–§ğ–²ğ–¯ğ—‹ğ– ğ–§ğ–²ğ–¯\mathsf{rAHSP}) and obtain the upper and lower bounds for the sample complexity of ğ—‹ğ– ğ–§ğ–²ğ–¯ğ—‹ğ– ğ–§ğ–²ğ–¯\mathsf{rAHSP}. iii) We continue to discuss a special case of ğ—‹ğ– ğ–§ğ–²ğ–¯ğ—‹ğ– ğ–§ğ–²ğ–¯\mathsf{rAHSP}, generalized Simonâ€™s problem (ğ–¦ğ–²ğ–¯ğ–¦ğ–²ğ–¯\mathsf{GSP}), and show that the sample complexity of ğ–¦ğ–²ğ–¯ğ–¦ğ–²ğ–¯\mathsf{GSP} is Î˜â€‹(maxâ¡{k,kâ‹…pnâˆ’k})Î˜ğ‘˜â‹…ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘˜\Theta\left(\max\left\{k,\sqrt{k\cdot p^{n-k}}\right\}\right). Thus we obtain a complete characterization of the sample complexity of ğ–¦ğ–²ğ–¯ğ–¦ğ–²ğ–¯\mathsf{GSP}.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 47 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 47"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Two new results about quantum exact learning",
        "Guest column: A survey of quantum learning theory",
        "Optimal quantum sample complexity of learning algorithms",
        "Quantum algorithms for learning and testing juntas",
        "From optimal measurement to efficient quantum algorithms for the hidden subgroup problem over semidirect product groups",
        "The true sample complexity of active learning",
        "Quantum cryptanalysis of hidden linear functions (extended abstract)",
        "An exact quantum polynomial-time algorithm for Simonâ€™s problem",
        "Learning DNF over the uniform distribution using a quantum example oracle",
        "Optimal separation in exact query complexities for Simonâ€™s problem",
        "Lecture notes on quantum algorithms",
        "Quantum algorithm for a generalized hidden shift problem",
        "The query complexity of order-finding",
        "Elements of Information Theory",
        "Quantum Computing: Lecture Notes",
        "Hidden symmetry subgroup problems",
        "Rapid solution of problems by quantum computation",
        "A quantum algorithm for computing the unit group of an arbitrary degree number field",
        "The quantum query complexity of the hidden subgroup problem is polynomial",
        "Hidden translation and orbit coset in quantum computing",
        "Quantum mechanical algorithms for the nonabelian hidden subgroup problem",
        "Fast quantum algorithms for computing the unit group and class group of a number field",
        "Polynomial-time quantum algorithms for Pellâ€™s equation and the principal ideal problem",
        "The hidden subgroup problem and quantum computation using group representations",
        "Theory of disagreement-based active learning",
        "The list-decoding size of Fourier-sparse Boolean functions",
        "Quantum measurements for hidden subgroup problems with optimal sample complexity",
        "Quantum Computing",
        "Efficient quantum algorithms for some instances of the non-Abelian hidden subgroup problem",
        "Quantum algorithms and the Fourier transform",
        "The hidden subgroup problem and permutation group theory",
        "Quantum measurements and the Abelian stabilizer problem",
        "A quantum lower bound for the query complexity of simonâ€™s problem",
        "A subexponential-time quantum algorithm for the dihedral hidden subgroup problem",
        "The power of strong Fourier sampling: Quantum algorithms for affine groups and hidden shifts",
        "For distinguishing conjugate hidden subgroups, the pretty good measurement is as good as it gets",
        "The hidden subgroup problem and eigenvalue estimation on a quantum computer",
        "Learning functions of kğ‘˜k relevant variables",
        "Deterministic algorithms for the hidden subgroup problem",
        "Quantum computation and lattice problems",
        "Polynomial time quantum algorithm for the computation of the unit group of a number field",
        "Algorithms for quantum computation: Discrete logarithms and factoring",
        "On the power of quantum computation",
        "Enumerative Combinatorics, Volume 1",
        "Learning DNF under the uniform distribution in quasi-polynomial time",
        "Lecture 6: Simonâ€™s algorithm",
        "Query complexity of generalized simonâ€™s problem"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 47 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Sample complexity of hidden subgroup problem, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
